title: 104_s899
content: The "Earned Income Tax Credit Fraud Prevention Act" amends the 1986 Code to deny the Earned Income Credit to individuals not authorized to work in the United States. The "Earned Income Tax Credit Fraud Prevention Act" denies the Earned Income Credit to individuals who do not provide their taxpayer identification numbers on their tax return, including their spouse's if married. The taxpayer identification number required for the Earned Income Credit is defined as a social security number issued by the Social Security Administration. Additionally, an omission of the correct taxpayer identification number is considered a clerical error under section 6213(g)(2) of the Act. The identification number required for tax credits must be included on a return. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 3 repeals the earned income credit for individuals without children and defines an eligible individual as someone with a qualifying child. It also amends tables in section 32(b) by removing items related to no qualifying children. The effective date is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. SEC. 4 decreases earned income credit amounts and phaseout ranges. SEC. 4 decreases earned income credit amounts and phaseout ranges by amending subsection (b) of section 32 to adjust credit and phaseout percentages. The earned income credit percentages and phaseout percentages for eligible individuals with qualifying children are specified. For taxable years beginning in 1996, the credit percentage for individuals with 2 or more qualifying children is 35 percent. For eligible individuals with qualifying children, the earned income amount and phaseout amount vary based on the number of qualifying children. Section 32(i) is amended to remove a specific reference, while section 32(j) is updated to terminate inflation adjustments after December 31, 1995. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after the same date. Additionally, rules regarding the denial of earned income credit based on disqualified income are addressed in Section 5. The definition of Disqualified Income in section 32(i) is expanded to include capital gain net income, excess income from passive activities, and amounts included in gross income under sections 652 or 662 for the taxable year. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. The amendments in section 32(i) decrease the amount of disqualified income allowed from $2,350 to $1,000 for taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. Modification of adjusted gross income definition for earned income credit. The definition of modified adjusted gross income for the earned income credit is amended to include social security benefits and amounts received for support from a divorce or separation instrument. The text discusses the tax treatment of child support payments, including exemptions for certain types of income and amounts received from qualified retirement plans. Additionally, the Secretary of the Treasury is required to conduct a study on the federal tax treatment of child support payments. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to conduct a study on the Federal tax treatment of child support payments, with recommendations to encourage payment of child support liabilities and make parents more responsible for a child's economic well-being. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1995. Earned Income Credit cannot be claimed until the employer's withholding statement is received. The earned income credit must be verified by comparing it with information from employee tax returns or self-employment tax returns. This verification is necessary for any advanced payment of the earned income credit. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1996. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a study on potential delays in processing tax returns due to the amendment and report findings to relevant committees within a year. SEC. 8. PREVENTION OF FRAUD IN ELECTRONIC RETURNS. The Secretary of the Treasury will require fingerprints and credit information from new electronic return originator applicants. Past applicants will also need to comply with these requirements.
